name: First-year Seminar
desc: The First-year Seminar Program is designed to provide new students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a faculty member in a small seminar setting. First-year seminars can be offered in all campus departments and undergraduate colleges, and topics vary from quarter to quarter.

name: Greek Seminar
desc: Readings in Greek covering specific topics in ancient Greek literature, philosophy, history, and religion. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.

name: Latin Seminar
desc: Readings in Latin covering specific topics in ancient Latin literature, philosophy, history, and religion. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.

name: Early Christianity
desc: This course examines the emergence, growth, and development of Christianity in its first centuries. The class explores issues of community, doctrine, and practice; inter-religious and intra-religious tension and conflict; and cultural continuity and change.

name: Classical Diversities
desc: This course explores the questions of race and gender in the classical world, together with their impact on the study of the classics in the making of American identity.

name: World Wisdom Traditions
desc: This online course explores wisdom traditions of the premodern world, examining formative ideas on the art of living well and contrasting worldwide teachings on what it means to be human, one's obligations to others, and the ideal relationship with the natural world.

name: Directed Honors Thesis in Classical Studies
desc: BA honors thesis research under the direction of a member of a classical studies program faculty.
misc_prereq: Acceptance into the classical studies honors program and consent of instructor.

name: Directed Group Study
desc: Directed group study on a topic not generally included in the regular curriculum. Student must make arrangements with individual faculty members. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.

name: Independent Study
desc: Independent study on a topic not generally included in the regular curriculum. Student must make arrangements with individual faculty members. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.

name: Contemporary Literary Theory and the Classics
desc: An introduction to contemporary literary theory, focusing on important critical approaches to the literary texts. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.

name: Diachronic Perspectives on Classical Antiquity
desc: Examines ways in which classical texts and ideas have been received and appropriated for the diverse purposes of ancient and subsequent cultures. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.

name: Greece and Rome in Their Contemporary Cultural Contexts
desc: An introduction to the methods and perspectives of social scientific theory that can be used to study the material and social dimensions of the cultures of ancient Greece and Rome. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.

name: Concurrent Readings
desc: May be repeated for credit as topics vary.

name: Classics Graduate Seminar
desc: Subject matter variable; mainly but not exclusively major literary topics. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.

name: Independent Study
desc: Supervised independent research. Subject varies. May be repeated for credit.

name: Research in Classics
desc: Research under Classics faculty. May be repeated for credit.

name: Dissertation Research
desc: Dissertation research with Classics faculty. May be repeated for credit.

name: University Teaching
desc: Required of and limited to teaching assistants. Satisfactory/unsatisfactory grade only. May be repeated for credit.
